Inspection of schools

What is a school inspection?

What types of school inspection are there?

Inspection reports

Further information

What is a school inspection?

All State primary and post-primary schools in Ireland are inspected by the Department of Education on a regular basis. An inspection is carried out to ensure that educational standards in schools are maintained.

The Department has a special division called the Inspectorate that carries out school inspections. The Education Act (1998) sets out the responsibilities of the Inspectorate.

The Inspectorate

Evaluates and reports on the quality of education provision

Inspects and evaluates education provision at primary and post-primary school

Advises those working in the education system

Contributes to the development of education policy

The Inspectorate also evaluates the educational services for students with special educational needs. This is separate to the role of the National Council for Special Education (NCSE) which helps improve co-ordination between education and health to provide special education.

The Child and Family Agency is responsible for assessing education provision for children who are not attending school .

What types of school inspection are there?

The Inspectorate carries out inspections in schools and centres for education and reports on these school inspections.

The inspections can include:

Curriculum evaluations

Whole School Evaluation

Child protection and safeguarding

Follow-through inspections look at how the school has implemented inspection recommendations

Whole School Evaluations (WSE)

Whole School Evaluations (WSE) are carried out in both primary and post- primary schools. A WSE assesses the quality of school management, teaching and learning at a school and assesses the school’s planning and self-review. The inspectorate may hold pre-evaluation meetings with staff and management, meet with the parents’ association and make school and classroom visits.

The inspectorate prepares a draft report and holds meetings with staff and management before finalising and issuing the Whole School Evaluation.

Inspection reports

You can find inspection reports for individual schools and Whole School Evaluations on the Department of Education’s website.

Further information

Department of Education

Inspectorate Secretariat Department of Education Marlborough Street Dublin 1 D01 RC96 Ireland

Tel: (01) 889 6553

**Question**:  
How does the Inspectorate's role in evaluating educational services for students with special educational needs interact with the responsibilities of the National Council for Special Education (NCSE), and what implications does this have for the coordination of special education in Ireland?

**Answer**:  
The Inspectorate and the NCSE share complementary but distinct roles in the context of special education in Ireland. The Inspectorate evaluates the quality of educational services provided to students with special educational needs, ensuring that these services meet established standards and are effectively implemented. This evaluation process includes assessing how well schools manage special education provision, the quality of teaching and support, and the extent to which students' needs are being met. The Inspectorate's evaluations are part of a broader mandate to assess educational provision across all State schools, including those with special education needs.

On the other hand, the NCSE focuses on improving coordination between educational and health services to provide special education. The NCSE acts as a catalyst for collaboration, ensuring that the needs of students with special educational needs are met through a cohesive and integrated approach. The NCSE works with schools, local authorities, and healthcare providers to develop and implement special education plans, and it also provides support and resources to schools to enhance their capacity to address the diverse needs of students.

The interaction between the Inspectorate and the NCSE is crucial for the effective coordination of special education. The Inspectorate's evaluations provide a quality assurance mechanism, ensuring that the services provided by schools are of a high standard and aligned with national guidelines. Meanwhile, the NCSE's role in fostering collaboration between education and health services ensures that the needs of students are met holistically, taking into account both educational and medical factors.

This division of responsibilities has several implications for the coordination of special education in Ireland. First, it ensures that there is a robust system in place to monitor and improve the quality of special education services. Second, it promotes a collaborative approach to meeting students' needs, integrating educational and health services. However, this division could also lead to potential overlaps or gaps in responsibilities, requiring careful coordination between the two bodies to ensure seamless service delivery. Overall, the interplay between the Inspectorate and the NCSE is essential for maintaining high standards of special education and ensuring that students with special educational needs receive the support they require.

You then ask the tax office to allocate the tax credits and standard rate cut- off point between you in whatever way you want. (The Employee Tax Credit, employment expenses and the increase in standard rate cut-off point of €33,000 in 2024 are not transferable).

You will both receive updated Tax Credit Certificates showing the allocation of your credits and rate band.

If Revenue does not get a request from you to allocate your tax credits in any particular way, it will normally give all the tax credits (other than the other partner's Employee and expense tax credits) to the spouse or civil partner being assessed. The spouse or civil partner being assessed must complete the return of income for the couple and is charged for tax on the joint income of the couple.

If one spouse or civil partner is self-employed, joint assessment can still apply. The flexibility this option brings can be convenient - especially if one of you pays tax under the PAYE system and the other pays tax under the self-assessment system. Under joint assessment, you let your circumstances determine if most of the tax should be paid under PAYE or in a lump sum on assessment. This is determined by the way in which the tax credits are allocated. If you choose to pay most of your tax under PAYE, your credits can be transferred to the self-employed person (but not employment expenses or the Employee Tax Credit).

If a refund is due at the end of the year, it will be repaid to each person in proportion to the amount of tax each has paid.

Rates

The standard rate cut-off point for married couples/civil partners is €51,000 in 2024. This amount is taxed at 20% and the balance is taxed at 40%. Where both spouses/civil partners have income, this standard rate cut-off point can be increased by the lower of the following:

€33,000 in 2024 or

The amount of the income of the spouse/civil partner with the smaller income.

You cannot claim this increase as well as the Home Carer Tax Credit . If you are eligible for both, contact your Revenue office to help you decide which would be best for you.

In 2023, the standard rate cut-off point for married couples/civil partners was €49,000, with a maximum increase of €31,000.

**Question**:  
How does the allocation of tax credits and the standard rate cut-off point between spouses or civil partners under joint assessment affect the overall tax liability, and what factors should couples consider when deciding how to allocate these credits?

**Answer**:  
Under joint assessment, couples have the flexibility to allocate tax credits and the standard rate cut-off point in a way that minimizes their overall tax liability. The standard rate cut-off point for married couples or civil partners in 2024 is €51,000, taxed at 20%, with the balance taxed at 40%. The cut-off point can be increased by up to €33,000, but this increase cannot be claimed alongside the Home Carer Tax Credit. Couples should consider their individual incomes, tax payment methods (PAYE vs. self-assessment), and eligibility for other tax credits when deciding how to allocate their credits. If one spouse is self-employed, transferring credits to the self-employed person under PAYE can be advantageous. Additionally, refunds are proportional to the tax each person has paid, so couples should ensure the allocation reflects their financial circumstances accurately. Revenue will default to giving all non-employment-related credits to the spouse or civil partner completing the return if no specific allocation is requested.
